newsitem.title: USA: U.S. agents say they have leads in Atlanta bombings.
newsitem.headline: U.S. agents say they have leads in Atlanta bombings.

text.p: Federal officials said Friday that they had received a number of leads in their investigation into this week's double bomb blasts outside an Atlanta abortion clinic.

U.S. Attorney Kent Alexander said information involving a range of possibilities, from anti-abortion activists to citizens' milita groups, had come from more than 200 telephone calls to a special federal hotline set up as an appeal for public assistance.

Meanwhile, he said, bomb sweeps were being conducted at other Atlanta-area abortion clinics and would continue through next week's 24th anniversary of the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling that recognised a woman's right to an abortion.
"So far, we've received over 200 calls," Alexander told reporters. "From those calls a number of good leads are developing."
Asked to elaborate further, the federal prosecutor described "a myriad of leads. Much of what you'd expect, ranging from people who are anti-abortion to militia."

He also revealed for the first time that investigators discovered shrapnel and bomb fragments some distance from the blast site, including some on the roof of a seven-story office building near the clinic.
"These were two very powerful bombs. The most remarkable thing about this case thus far is that no one was killed," Alexander said.

The first bomb exploded about 9:30 a.m. EST (1430 GMT) Thursday outside the Atlanta Northside Family Planning Services centre. An hour later, as law enforcement officials and local firefighters sifted through debris, a second bomb detonated near a garbage container in the building's parking lot, injuring six people including agents from the FBI and the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
Police said there was no warning of the attack and no one claimed responsibility.
